choices.text: Enophthalmos within 24 hours of the fracture
Rapid improvement in traumatic diplopia over a 24-hour period
Unilateral midfacial sensory loss (V2 distribution unilaterally)

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most commonly associated with orbital floor fractures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The finding most commonly associated with orbital floor fracture is unilateral midfacial sensory loss (V2 distribution unilaterally).

  • Blow-out fractures of the orbital floor fractures frequently involve the thin bony encasement of the infraorbital nerve, a branch of the maxillary nerve (V2) in the orbital It presents as anaesthesia involving the lower lid, cheek, side of the nose, and upper lip on the affected side.
  • Other signs include diplopia, enophthalmos, ecchymosis, and subcutaneous emphysema.

Explanation of other options:

Orbital cellulitis (Option A): The most common foci of infection which causes orbital cellulitis is paranasal sinuses (ethmoid) and is not commonly associated with orbital floor fracture.

Enophthalmos within 24 hours of the fracture (Option B): While enophthalmos can occur in severe fractures, it is typically not evident within the first 24 hours due to periorbital oedema. It usually becomes more apparent after a few days as the swelling subsides.

Rapid improvement in traumatic diplopia over a 24-hour period (Option C): Diplopia can result from various mechanisms following orbital trauma, such as orbital haemorrhage, oedema, direct trauma to the extraocular muscles, or mechanical entrapment-ost often affecting the inferior rectus or inferior oblique muscles-ithin a fracture. Recovery may take around two months, but in cases with significant muscle involvement, diplopia may persist for a longer period.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the casualty with a history of blunt trauma to the eye. Which of the following is not an indication for surgical repair?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Improving diplopia is not an indication for surgical repair in orbital floor fractures.

  • The management of orbital floor fractures focuses on preventing permanent functional deficits such as persistent diplopia or cosmetically significant enophthalmos. Surgical repair is indicated when there is entrapment of orbital contents (Option B ruled out), enophthalmos greater than 2 mm (Option A ruled out), or persistent diplopia in the primary position.
  • Another important indication is the 'white-eyed' fracture, a condition typically seen in younger patients with minimal external signs but significant soft tissue entrapment and oculocardiac symptoms. It demands urgent repair to prevent permanent neuromuscular damage. (Option D ruled out)

choices.text: The orbital floor medial to the infraorbital nerve
The orbital aspect of the zygoma
The orbital aspect of the maxilla and inferior orbital rim
The orbital floor lateral to the infraorbital nerve

questions.text: A 24-year-old man was involved in an automobile accident in which his face struck the dashboard. He denies any loss of consciousness, but says his vision is blurred in the right eye. After clinical examination, a provisional diagnosis of blow-out fracture is made. What is the most common location of an orbital blowout fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common site of an orbital blowout fracture is the orbital floor medial to the infraorbital nerve.

  • A blow-out fracture of the orbital floor usually occurs when a blunt object larger than the orbital opening (approximately 5 cm in diameter) strikes the orbital area. This causes a sudden rise in intraorbital pressure, forcing the eyeball to shift backwards and transmit the force to the surrounding orbital walls, rather than absorbing it.
  • Because the lateral orbital wall and roof are structurally stronger and more resistant to impact, fractures most commonly affect the orbital floor, which is thinnest just medial to the infraorbital canal (Options B, C, and D ruled out). In some cases, the medial orbital wall may also be involved.
  • Features of blow-out fractures include sensory loss due to involvement of the infraorbital nerve, diplopia, enophthalmos, and subcutaneous emphysema.

choices.text: Motility examination of the cardinal positions of gaze

questions.text: What is the best way to distinguish a restrictive motility disorder from a paretic disorder after a blowout fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The best way to distinguish a restrictive ophthalmoplegia from a paretic motility disorder after a blow-out fracture is forced duction testing.

  • Ophthalmoplegia can be caused by a variety of conditions, including space-occupying lesions within the orbit, inflammatory or restrictive muscle disorders such as thyroid eye disease or orbital myositis, and mechanical entrapment of the extraocular muscles following orbital wall fractures. Additionally, involvement of the cranial nerves that control eye movement may occur due to lesions located in the posterior orbit, superior orbital fissure, or cavernous sinus. Examples of such conditions include carotid-avernous fistula, Tolosa-unt syndrome, and malignant tumours of the lacrimal gland.
  • To distinguish between a restrictive cause and a neurogenic cause of ophthalmoplegia, several clinical tests may be used. The forced duction test, performed under topical anaesthesia, involves gently manipulating the globe in the direction of limited movement. If resistance is felt, it suggests a mechanical restriction, whereas smooth passive movement points to a neurological cause.
  • Another useful method is the differential intraocular pressure (IOP) test, in which a difference in pressure of 6 mmHg or more when measured in primary gaze and when the patient attempts to look in the restricted direction supports the presence of a mechanical restriction, a finding known as the Braley sign. Assessment of saccadic eye movements can also be useful to distinguish between restrictive and paretic causes.

Explanation of other options:

Alternate prism cover testing (Option A): The alternate prism cover test helps to measure the degree of deviation in strabismus, but cannot be used to differentiate between restrictive and neurological causes.

Goldmann perimeter (Option B): The Goldmann perimeter can be used to assess the field of binocular single vision and is used in the assessment of strabismus.

Motility examination of the cardinal positions of gaze (Option C): There are nine diagnostic positions of gaze in which ocular deviations are measured. This includes the six cardinal positions, the primary position, elevation and depression.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common sign of an orbital blowout fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tenderness over the zygomaticofrontal suture is not a common sign of an orbital blowout fracture.

  • An orbital blowout fracture typically results from a sudden increase in intraorbital pressure due to trauma from an object larger than the orbital aperture, such as a fist or tennis ball. This force is transmitted to the orbital walls, most commonly causing a fracture in the orbital floor. Infraorbital nerve hypoesthesia is common and presents as numbness over the lower lid, cheek, side of the nose, and upper lip. (Option B ruled out)
  • Diplopia frequently occurs, particularly in upward gaze (supraduction), due to entrapment or restricted movement of the inferior rectus or inferior oblique muscles. (Option C ruled out)
  • Enophthalmos may also develop as orbital contents herniate into the maxillary sinus through the fracture. (Option D ruled out)
  • However, tenderness over the zygomaticofrontal suture is more indicative of trauma to the zygomatic complex rather than an isolated orbital floor fracture. Therefore, it is not a characteristic or common sign of a blowout fracture.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best study to detect metallic orbital foreign bodies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Computerised tomography is the best study to detect metallic orbital foreign bodies.

CT provides high-resolution images useful in assessing both the location and potential complications associated with orbital foreign bodies. It is also valuable in evaluating the integrity of intracranial, facial, and intraocular structures. CT is especially advantageous over MRI because it does not pose the risk associated with magnetic fields, which could mobilise metallic fragments. It also provides more detailed anatomic imaging than plain films.

Explanation of other options:

Magnetic resonance imaging (option A): MRI is contraindicated if a ferrous metallic foreign body is suspected, as the magnetic field may cause the metal to shift, potentially worsening the injury.

Sonography (option B): Although useful in detecting intraocular abnormalities, it is less useful compared to computed tomography.

Plain films (option C): Plain films can demonstrate metallic foreign bodies but lack the sensitivity and detail that CT offers, especially when localisation and evaluation of surrounding tissue damage is necessary.

questions.text: What is the study of choice for the evaluation of fractures in acute orbital trauma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Computerised tomography is the study of choice for the evaluation of fractures in acute orbital trauma.

  • Computed tomography with coronal sections is particularly useful for assessing the extent of orbital fractures and evaluating the nature of associated maxillary antral soft-tissue densities. These densities may indicate herniation of orbital contents such as fat or extraocular muscles into the maxillary sinus, or the presence of a haematoma. This can be seen as the tear drop sign on CT and plain radiographs, both of which are shown below.

Explanation of other options:

Orbital ultrasound (Option A): Sonography is not suitable to visualise orbital fractures.

Magnetic resonance imaging (Option B): MRI, while excellent for soft tissue evaluation, is not ideal for assessing bone fractures and is not typically used in the acute trauma setting. It is also contraindicated in the presence of metallic foreign bodies.

Nerve conduction studies (Option D): Nerve conduction studies are not used to assess orbital fractures.

questions.text: What is the next best step if a patient presents with blood-tinged tears?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Biopsy of the lacrimal sac is the next best step when a patient presents with blood-tinged tears.

  • Primary lacrimal sac tumours are rare but can present as masses at the medial canthus and may cause bloody tearing. These tumours are often epithelial in origin and may not initially obstruct tear flow, which explains why patients often have a patent nasolacrimal system until the lumen is affected.
  • A biopsy of the lacrimal sac is crucial to establish a definitive diagnosis in a patient who presents with blood-tinged tears to rule out lacrimal sac malignancy.

Explanation of other options:

Balloon dacryocystoplasty (Option A): A procedure primarily reserved for partial nasolacrimal duct obstruction. It is not indicated when a lacrimal sac tumour is suspected.

Probing and tube placement (Option C): Used in cases of congenital or acquired nasolacrimal duct obstruction, but fails to address or diagnose the underlying pathology when a mass is involved.

Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) (Option D): A bypass procedure that restores tear drainage by creating an anastomosis between the lacrimal sac and nasal mucosa; however, performing a DCR without first ruling out malignancy could risk spreading tumour cells and delaying appropriate treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common indication for repair of medial orbital wall fractures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Entrapment of the medial rectus muscle is the most common indication for surgical repair of medial orbital wall fractures.

  • Medial wall orbital fractures are frequently seen in conjunction with floor fractures and rarely occur in isolation. Entrapment of the medial rectus leads to mechanical restriction of eye movements and presents as defective ocular motility during abduction and adduction. Repair in such cases aims to release the incarcerated muscle and correct the bony defect, which helps restore full ocular motility and prevent long-term complications such as fibrosis or muscle dysfunction.

Explanation of other options:

Epiphora (Option A): Epiphora is commonly associated with nasolacrimal duct obstruction and is not directly caused by medial wall fractures. 

Entrapment of the inferior rectus muscle (Option B): More commonly associated with orbital floor fractures.

Sinusitis (Option C): May coexist with facial trauma, but is not an indication for orbital wall repair.

choices.text: Repair both injuries at the same time
Repair the ruptured globe immediately and delay the floor exploration for 2 to 4 weeks
Wait 48 hours and then repair both injuries at the same time
Repair the ruptured globe immediately and delay the floor exploration for 4 months

questions.text: If a patient has a ruptured globe in addition to a symptomatic blowout fracture, what should the surgeon do?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The surgeon should promptly repair the ruptured globe and delay orbital floor exploration for 2 to 4 weeks.

  • Globe rupture typically occurs at weak points in the sclera or cornea due to blunt trauma and may be anterior or posterior. Common locations include areas behind the extraocular muscles (particularly in the superonasal quadrant), previous intraocular surgical incision sites, and the lamina cribrosa. It is associated with a profoundly soft eye due to low intraocular pressure, hemorrhagic chemosis (as shown below), and structural deformation. Once confirmed or even strongly suspected, an immediate protective shield should be applied, and urgent ophthalmic surgical repair must be performed as soon as feasible. (Option C ruled out)
  • If the patient also presents with a symptomatic blowout fracture, surgical repair can be delayed by 2 to 4 weeks (Option A and D ruled out). This delay allows resolution of inflammation and swelling, minimising intraoperative complications such as elevated intraorbital pressure. However, blowout fractures with severe pain and/or autonomic disturbance necessitate urgent surgical intervention.

questions.text: What is the most common eye condition associated with the use of topical latanoprost?
questions.solution:
Side effects of latanoprost include hypertrichosis, increased pigmentation of eyelashes and eyelids, hyperpigmentation of the iris, and mild conjunctival hyperemia.

Reference: Kanski 8th edition/331

questions.text: What is this surgical procedure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows an anophthalmic socket following evisceration, a procedure involving the removal of the intraocular contents.

  • Evisceration involves removing all intraocular contents, usually via a corneal opening, while preserving the sclera and extraocular muscles. This retention allows better motility of orbital implants post-surgery compared to enucleation, which disrupts extraocular muscle attachment.
  • Evisceration is generally used in blind, painful, or disfigured eyes. It is contraindicated in intraocular malignancy, as histological examination of the full globe is not possible.

Explanation of other options:

Excision of eye (Option A): A vague and non-specific term that doesn' correspond to a recognised surgical procedure in ophthalmology.

Enucleation (Option B) refers to the complete removal of the globe, including the sclera, but preserving the surrounding orbital tissues, and is indicated in intraocular malignancies or severe trauma.

Exenteration (Option C): A more extensive surgery that involves the removal of the globe along with surrounding orbital tissues, often used for orbital malignancies.

questions.text: This surgical procedure is indicated for?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tumours of the eyeball, specifically primary intraocular malignancies, are a major indication for enucleation, the surgical procedure shown.

  • Enucleation is the removal of the entire globe, with preservation of the orbital soft tissues, making it the procedure of choice when dealing with intraocular malignancies such as retinoblastoma or uveal melanoma. This is because enucleation leaves the globe intact, allowing the tumour to be preserved for histopathological examination, which is essential for diagnosis and treatment planning.

Explanation of other options:

Severe corneal ulcer (Option B): It is typically managed initially with antibiotics, steroids, and mydriatics. Keratoplasty may be required in dense residual corneal scarring.

Severe uveitis (Option C): It is managed with steroids and cycloplegics.

Endophthalmitis (Option D): If severe and unresponsive to medical management, may sometimes be managed with evisceration, not enucleation, unless intraocular malignancy is also suspected.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a characteristic feature of blunt trauma to the eye?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sunflower cataract is not a characteristic feature of blunt trauma to the eye.

  • Blunt ocular trauma is associated with a variety of anterior and posterior segment injuries.
  • Characteristic manifestations include hyphaema (shown below) due to rupture of vessels in the iris or ciliary body, raised intraocular pressure (IOP) either from trabecular meshwork damage or secondary inflammation.
  • Traumatic cataract commonly presents as rosette-shaped cataracts (shown below) in the posterior subcapsular cortex or ring-shaped anterior subcapsular opacities.
  • Commotio retinae, a transient whitening of the retina due to photoreceptor outer segment disruption, is also commonly observed after blunt trauma, especially in the posterior pole. It is shown below.
  • In contrast, sunflower cataract is classically associated with Wilson's isease, where copper deposition leads to a petal-like anterior lens opacity.

questions.text: In case of penetrating injury to the eye,1st thing to be done is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The immediate step in managing a penetrating eye injury is to protect the eye by applying a rigid shield (patch and bandage) to prevent further damage.

  • Applying pressure, irrigating, or administering medication before stabilising the injury may exacerbate damage. Patching and bandaging ensure that intraocular structures are not further displaced or exposed while awaiting surgical repair. Furthermore, early coverage also limits contamination and infection risk.
  • Once the eye is stabilised, systemic antibiotics, tetanus prophylaxis, imaging, and surgical repair can proceed in an organised and controlled manner.

Explanation of other options:

Administering antibiotics (Option B): While necessary for preventing infection, it is not the first action.

Steroids (Option C): They are used in traumatic optic neuropathy.

Washing with water (Option D): It is used in the initial management of corrosive injuries of the eye.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions can the finding in the image be seen? Options:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a D-shaped pupil, which is a characteristic finding in iridodialysis.

  • Iridodialysis refers to the dehiscence of the iris from the ciliary body at its root and is commonly associated with blunt trauma to the eye. This is in contrast to cyclodialysis, which is the circular separation of the peripheral iris and ciliary body from the sclera at the scleral spur. Both may need surgical intervention if large or if associated with hypotony.

Explanation of other options:

Lens dislocation (Option A): Blunt trauma can result in zonular disruption and dislocation of the lens, which can result in secondary glaucoma. It is also associated with Marfan's syndrome and homocystinuria. It does not cause a D-shaped pupil.

High intraocular pressure (Option C), such as in acute angle-closure glaucoma, typically causes a mid-dilated fixed pupil, not the flat-edge deformation seen in iridodialysis.

Iridocyclitis (Option D), or anterior uveitis, leads to irregular, small pupils due to posterior synechiae and inflammation.
